title: Can quantum physics explain consciousness? - Quora

response.answer_text: At present, nothing explains subjective experience (“consciousness”). But it’s pretty easy to argue that the unknown explanation must involve basic-level, fundamental physics of some sort. Whether that physics would be “quantum physics” remains to be seen. Here’s the really short version of the argument. One possibility is that subjective experience is identical to certain brain states (biological or functional), the way water is identical to H2O. This idea has been widely considered by philosophers. It is universally agreed that if it is true, then the relationship of the subjective to the physical is a set of “brute facts” which permit no further analysis, especially no evolutionary analysis. We accept a small number of brute facts in physics, and every physicist is at work trying to reduce that number to a bare minimum. But one brute fact for every type of experience (each taste, each color, every sort of feeling …)? That seems very unlikely. And the brute facts about pleasure and suffering being identical to their corresponding brain states would make a creationist blush. Oh, and many philosophers believe the whole idea is simply false. (Spoiler alert: it is.) The next possibility is that subjective experience is a strongly emergent property of certain brain states. This means that the brain states produce subjectivity the way certain arrangements of matter produce liquidity or solidity, with the key difference (the “strong” part) being that, unlike the latter cases, there is no way of deducing or explaining subjectivity, beginning from the corresponding brain states. (If you could, that would mean they were ultimately identical, just like chemistry is ultimately identical to physics. And that’s the answer we just dismissed). Now, we would then have to ask the question, why do brain states have this unique ability to produce subjective experience via strong emergence? Well, we think we understand the basic material nature of brain states completely. They reduce (are ultimately identical to) basic-level physics! So, if subjectivity is a strongly emergent property of brain biology, then the explanation for that is passed down to basic-level physics, where there must be something we’re unaware of. And if subjectivity is a strongly emergent property of brain functional states, then the same thing is true, except this is much more promising. Since the brain’s function is to process information, then the something we’re unaware of about basic-level physics could well be a fundamental theory of information, which a lot of physicists are currently chasing (though not with an eye to explaining subjectivity). Finally, it’s possible that subjective experience (or the potential for it) is a fundamental property of all matter. Again, this is a basic-level, fundamental physics solution. Edit: a year and a half later I wrote another answer, quite shorter answer, before questions were merged. Here it is: I believe you’re asking whether the solution to the Hard Problem of Consciousness [1] is likely to involve QM. As I’m fond of repeating continually, it’s quite easy to demonstrate that the solution must involve new basic-level physics. It cannot be just a product of ordinary brain activity as we understand it. Here (for the first time on Quora!) is a modification of a famous argument to that effect, from David Chalmer’s The Conscious Mind. My additions are in bold italics [2]. In our world, there are conscious experiences.Given our present knowledge of physics, there is a logically possible world physically identical to ours, in which the positive facts about consciousness do not hold.Therefore, facts about consciousness are further facts about the world, over and above the physical facts as we presently understand them.However, I think it is likely that the missing physical facts about consciousness are deeper than QM and will help make sense of it. Eric M. Van's answer to How long do you think it will be until a single interpretation of quantum mechanics beats the others (because of scientific evidence, not popular opinion)? [1] How and why do we have subjective experience of the top-level information processing in the brain, when that subjective experience doesn’t seem to add anything to our behavior? [2] The additions reflect the increasing recognition that we always redefine “the physical” to include whatever it takes to explain the observed world.

Almost nothing. If you’re referring to the observer effect, then it says absolutely nothing about consciousness. When one makes an “observation” of quantum phenomena, that doesn’t mean they’re intently staring at it - it means that they’re using a particle detector which physically interacts with the quantum particle in question. It has nothing to do with a conscious human observing the particle - it’s merely a physical interaction between particles that collapses the wave function. That being said, I see a lot of answers on here about how quantum physics has nothing to do with consciousness, which isn’t entirely true. If we don’t frame this question in reference to the observer effect, then quantum physics actually makes a very interesting (but also useless) prediction about human decision making and free will. In a hypothetical universe identical to ours, but instead governed only by classical mechanics, human decisions would be fixed and unalterable. That means that you could predict someone’s “fate”, if you had all the information currently present in that universe. This is because the particles in that universe would evolve only according to classical mechanics, and would thus interact in a perfectly predictable way. In our actual universe, which is governed by the laws of quantum mechanics, nothing is fixed, and nothing is predictable with absolute certainty. In fact, there is even a minuscule probability that if you jumped in the air outside right now, you could jump high enough to escape (ie. quantum tunnel through) Earth’s gravitational pull and leave the atmosphere - the probability is somewhere around the order of 10^(-10^54), by my calculations. Therefore, we can assert that human decision making is not fixed or predictable either. Does this give us any actionable information on human consciousness? Not really, it just says that rather than our fate being fixed, our fate is completely arbitrary - we still wouldn’t have free will either way - but in the philosophical debate on free will vs. determinism, it shows that both are scientifically inaccurate (there really should be an option for randomism).

Actually, that approach is backwards. Imagine trying to use quantum physics to explain chemistry. The fact is that when atoms interact, a process, new rules arise. Imagine trying to use physics and chemistry to explain how a cell works. Cells work at a process level, not a physical or chemical level. Imagine using cells to try and explain how tissues work. Tissues survive and thrive when cells cooperate, and fail when cells fail to cooperate successfully. Imagine using tissues to explain how limbs and organs work. Limbs and organs can only emerge when tissues cooperate. Imagine using limbs and organs to explain how limbs coordinate and how organ systems work. Organ systems only work when multiple organs in an individual body cooperate with each other. Imagine using limb coordination and organ systems to explain how the body works. The body only works when every layer actively cooperates. Nothing about cells, in isolation can explain the body. Imagine using nervous tissue and brain components to explain how the brain works. Imagine using sensory organs to explain how feelings work. Imagine using information about how the body works, to explain how families work. In each of those cases, there is a small, often only a single layer jump UPWARDS in the hierarchy. Let’s imagine two or more layer jumps. Imagine using quantum physics to explain how a cell works. Imagine using our knowledge of cells to explain how limbs and organs work. Imagine using knowledge about cells to explain how the respiratory system works. Imagine using knowledge about limbs and organs to explain how families work. Consciousness pervades the hierarchy of life. Cells are conscious of their internal and external environments, and make life decisions based on that consciousness. Tissues are conscious of their internal and their external environments. They use that knowledge to make life decisions. Limbs and organs are conscious of their limb and organ environments - which have nothing to do with cellular environments or tissue environments. Limbs and organs function in their environment, which includes the bodily systems they are part of. Any multi cellular organism has body consciousness - more or less, and they use that consciousness to survive, to succeed and to reproduce. If that consciousness fails. Animals with brains have a higher level of consciousness, which often includes consciousness of their families and their communities. Humans, and a few animals have ‘self consciousness’. Awareness of themselves, and use that level of consciousness to survive and thrive. Attempting to go down the hierarchy, to quantum physics, to explain how something near the top of the hierarchy, something that also pervades the hierarchy throughout, is a failure to understand, and a failure to understand the nature of the hierarchy. We can use examples from quantum physics, to find relationships that help us understand consciousness. We can use examples from quantum physics to build models that help us to understand consciousness. But to suppose there is a direct link between the two is speculation, without any possibility of being actually demonstrated or proven by a scientific analysis. to your health, tracy

I don’t think so. Here’s what I wrote in my book “Fields of Color” in a section called “The Gaps”: Finally, we come to the grand-daddy of mysteries. How dare physicists talk about “theories of everything” when they can’t explain what goes on behind their very noses! As humans, we can identify galaxies light years away, we can study particles smaller than an atom. But we still haven’t unlocked the mystery of the three pounds of matter that sits between our ears. - B. Obama (remarks by the president on the BRAIN Initiative, April 2, 2013) But please understand, by consciousness I don’t mean simple information processing, such as can be done by any computer. I mean the sense of awareness, the sensations and feelings that our minds experience every day – from the color red to the beauty of a Mozart sonata or the pain of a toothache. Such sensations are known as qualia. Most physicists don’t want to be bothered with the question, and it is left to philosophers like Charlie Chaplin to worry about it: Billions of years it’s taken to evolve human consciousness… The miracle of all existence… More important than anything in the whole universe. What can the stars do? Nothing but sit on their axis! And the sun, shoot­ing flames 280,000 miles high. So what? Wasting all its natural resources. Can the sun think? Is it conscious? — C. Chaplin (film “Limelight”, 1952) I see consciousness as a more pressing problem than the question of why the field constants have the values they do. My concern began when I was thinking about pain. Pain surely cannot be explained by fields or particles or relativity, or even quantum field theory, nor can pleasurable sensa­tions, like the enjoyment of music or the intense pleasure of an orgasm. Then one day we had a visitor - a young computer hot shot. As we were sitting down for dinner, I asked him "Do you think a computer can ever expe­rience a sexual orgasm?" Well this young fellow began to tell me how you could create an orgasm by putting 0's and 1's into the right memory banks. Of course this was nonsense, so I told him he had flunked the test and couldn't have any dinner. I didn’t really; we fed him, but it gave me the idea to write a book I was going to give it the title “Do Robots Have Orgasms?” (the illustration shows the cover designed by my nephew Roger L. Brooks), but I eventually abandoned the project because I figured that a book that boiled down to one word (“no”) wouldn't sell. However, I had already written or sketched chapters with proposed explanations, and while working on the Quantum Mechanics chapter, I realized that all the quantum mechanical ex­planations ignored QFT. That’s when I realized that QFT is ignored almost everywhere, as if it never existed. Or if it is mentioned, it is not the “fields only” version created by Julius Schwinger. And that’s why I wrote the book that I wrote. Is there any prospect that the consciousness mystery will ever be solved? Ambrose Bierce didn’t think so. To quote from his Devil’s Dictionary: Mind, n. A mysterious form of matter secreted by the brain. Its chief activity consists in the endeavor to ascertain its own nature, the futility of the attempt being due to the fact that it has nothing but itself to know itself with. – Ambrose Bierce You can read the entire final chapter free here. Or if you just want to learn more about Julian Schwinger, the unsung genius who perfected Quantum Field Theory, check out my viral Quora “tribute” (over 350,000 views) here.

Conventional answer: No. Neither quantum nor classical physics explain the existence, diversity, phenomenal binding and causal efficacy of consciousness. The Hard Problem is an unfathomable mystery.(cf. New mysterianism - Wikipedia) Non-materialist physicalist answer: Yes. Quantum mechanics (i.e. QFT or its extension) is formally complete. The superposition principle of QM never breaks down. You consist of quadrillions of "cat states" (cf. Quantum superposition - Wikipedia). Only the universal validity of the superposition principle allows your CNS to run phenomenally bound world-simulations featuring classical-looking cats and determinate pointer-readings (cf. Correspondence principle - Wikipedia). Decohered classical neurons can’t phenomenally simulate a classical world. You’d just be Jamesian “mind-dust” (cf. Classics in the History of Psychology -- James (1890) Chapter 6). But coherent quantum minds can simulate classical worlds - and they've been doing so for over 540 million years. Quantum physics explains why you’re not a micro-experiential zombie. (cf. China brain - Wikipedia) This possibility is counterintuitive. After all, back-of-an-envelope calculation suggests that thermally-induced decoherence "destroys" (i.e. scrambles the phase angles of components of) neuronal superpositions inside your skull within femtoseconds or less (cf. Maximilian Schlosshauer, Minimal no-collapse quantum mechanics). There exists no Divine Moviemaker to sculpt coherent superpositions of distributed neuronal feature-processors into the well-behaved macroscopic world-simulation that you're undergoing right now. Intuitively, neuronal superpositions are just vanishingly short-lived psychotic "noise". Maybe so. Yet recall Paley's Divine Watchmaker. Just as the workings of the evolutionary processes of natural selection are analogous to a Blind Watchmaker (cf. The Blind Watchmaker - Wikipedia), the far more powerful and unrelenting selection pressure of quantum Darwinism (cf. “Quantum Darwinism as a Darwinian Process”) in your CNS is akin to a Blind Moviemaker. A shame about the script. What about “mangled” frames? Well, they are real too on pain of violating unitarity. Evolution is wasteful. Note that despite unfamiliar terminology, the selection mechanism of Zurek's quantum Darwinism that explains the emergence of mind-independent classicality from quantum reality isn't the name of a speculative modification of the unitary Schrödinger dynamics (cf. Quantum Darwinism - Wikipedia). Rather, it’s just an extension of the decoherence program in post-Everett QM. Whether quantum Darwinism playing out inside our heads can also explain phenomenally bound conscious mind will be known only when molecular matter-wave interferometry independently deciphers the non-classical signature. (cf. Toward quantum superposition of living organisms) Noise or a perfect structural match?(cf. Schrödinger’s Neurons)I can guess; but intuitions are cheap.

Not quantum physics, but quantum metaphysics/mysticism does have “explanations.” At the micro level “physics” is thrown out the window. The laws are very different and strange. At the quantum metaphysics/mysticism dimension, the “time reversals,” and centrifuge coil of light surrounding us that “warps” timespace, running rings around us in a fourth dimension ends up, for us, having to use some crude anthropomorphic grasp for mind boggling profound implications. For example, in an en masse’ view, so called “consciousness” is a different aspect of the same. That is, what we define as “consciousness” may be a “cheap imitation” of something that is so dumb that it outsmarts us, like computer storage and retrieval. CONSCIOUSNESS = AWARENESS OF ‘IT,’ Whatever ‘IT’ IS. That means the universe does not have to “think” at least how we think. “In Einstein’s vision, the universe is like an organism in which each part is the manifestation of the whole” (Synchronicity: The Bridge Between Matter and Mind p 76). It is us that is made in the same image, not the other way around. Each individual is a “mirror image” a “copy” impressed with a “whole” and “parts.” Everyone is composed of sub particles, atoms and molecules, chemical dna, bacteria, organs and so on (multiplicity) and simultaneously act as a person (unity). The same pattern is impressed upon the social structure, if we can see it. Alvin Toffler in Foreword to Nobel Prize recipient Ilya Prigogine, and Isabelle Stengers book, Order Out of Chaos, says, “Imagine a situation in which a chemical or other reaction produces an enzyme whose presence then encourages further production of the same enzyme. This is an example of what computer scientists would call a positive-feedback loop. In chemistry it is called ‘auto-catalysis.’ Such situations are rare in inorganic chemistry. But in recent decades the molecular biologists have found that such loops (along with inhibitory or "negative" feedback and more complicated "cross-catalytic" processes) are the very stuff of life itself. Such processes help explain how we go from little lumps of DNA to complex living organisms. More generally, therefore, in far-from-equilibrium conditions we find that very small perturbations or fluctuations can become amplified into gigantic, structure-breaking waves. And this sheds light on all sorts of "qualitative" or "revolutionary" change processes. When one combines the new insights gained from studying far-from-equilibrium states and nonlinear processes, along with these complicated feedback systems, a whole new approach is opened that makes it possible to relate the so-called hard sciences to the softer sciences of life-and perhaps even to social processes as well” (Order Out Of Chaos p vii). Mathematician physicist and theoretical physicist Professor Wolfgang Pauli, during his initiation into philo linguistic symbolism occurring in his dreams has a dream illustration, his “countries mandala” that acts similar to an individual “I.” The “unconscious” acts as if oscillating back into the physical consciousness.  Ironically analogous to his own Pauli Exclusion principle, where electrons appear simultaneously as if jumped into another level, he uses the same four functions of the psyche’ that the psychiatrist Dr. Carl Jung used in therapy for the individual. It is as if the individual “I” jumps into another spectral coherent orbit or level to emerge as a sort of Ultra Human with a collective “I.” Pauli preferred to use the term “u-field” when around physicists rather than the psychological terminology. He said, “All sorts ideas crossed my mind on hearing this: Among physicists I sometimes use the term ‘U-field’ for the unconscious ...” (Atom and Archetype p 144). Paleontologist theologian Pere’ Pierre Tielhard de Chardin admitted, “No doubt it is true, scientifically speaking, that no distinct centre of superhuman consciousness has yet appeared on earth ( at least in the living world ) for which it may be claimed or predicted that one day it will exercise a centralizing function, in relation to the associated human thought, similar to the role of the individual ‘I’ in relation to the cells of the brain” (The Future of Man p 174). Tielhard’s vision of a thinking earth and noosphere, thinking sphere that embraces a thinking planet and expands beyond the galaxies can be compared with Professor Pauli’s dream vision. Depth Psychologist Dr. Ira Progoff suggested that we compare Tielhards’ noosphere with the work of Pauli and Jung’s collective unconscious and synchronicity (Jung, Synchronicity and Human Destiny pp 7–10). Tielhard expands and persists with his vision that likewise expands past the consciousness of an individual “I.” He says, “…what I have called its 'Brain'. As in the case of all the organisms preceding it, but on an immense scale, humanity is in process of 'cerebralising' itself. And our proper biological course, in making use of what we call our leisure, is to devote it to a new kind of work on a higher plane: that is to say, to a general and con­certed effort of vision. The Noosphere, in short, is a stupendous thinking machine.” (The Future of Man p 180). Mythologist Joseph Campbell, during one of his interviews with Bill Moyers, suggested that we “look past the physical and see the world as a poem.”  The sonnet above, composed between 1981–1983, is thematic of the “thinking earth.” The physical reality has been transformed into poetics. In order to comprehend such a mind boggling and outside the capability of physics and quantum physics to “explain” one must be able to view the world as one humongous picture with all areas of knowledge and discipline being pieces to the puzzle so that with the love of wisdom can at least catch glimpses of an operation that acts as if the same as consciousness. We’d have to shed our conception that the only SPACE in town is the electro magnetic coordinate system. Most third dimension inhabitants believe that the ‘past’ vanished, the ‘future’ is a not yet existent occurrence for a very narrow perspective of ‘the present.’ Two days prior to his death, Einstein said, “Past, present and future, as persistent as they are, is an illusion.” The problem with a physical mentality is that it is a mental con game that seems to dismiss and exclude any methodology that would seem disturbing or ruining their conception of reality. A “universal clock” may operate mostly undetected right under and over the heads, nose and eyes, eluding thresholds of awareness. That does not mean to suggest we should give up our reliable and trustworthy clocks. It’s just that science requires a “resolution” when studying micro and macro and infinite ‘points’ like monads are not part of ‘measured time.’ The existence of ‘unmeasured time’ does not help physical scientists because there is no way to measure length, breadth and width and calculate distance and where some object will be at some time in the future. Professor of Higher Mathematics, Ferdinand Gonseth suggests, “...have taken a further step, not only towards the objectivation of the measurement of time, but also towards the objectivation of time itself When will this procedure of extension have reached its term? Principally never. In practice one must observe moderation. In a Situation of well-defined knowledge, it is useless to increase indefinitely the possibilities of control and of synchronicity. "But what gives us the right, we might ask, to stop the process of extension at this point? If one does not admit the existence of an objective and universal time, is it not a fault of method to assume that the controls of synchronicity which have been erected would guarantee those which were not yet erected? Is it admissible to exclude as impossible the ease of an instrument still "unpublished" which could not be easily fitted into the group of clocks presently in use? We have already answered this question indirectly. It is not necessary t o construct all possible clocks; it suffices to establish the temporal law of the phenomena. As long as this temporal law does not vary with regard to the moment when the phenomenon begins (this Variation certainly could not be attributed to any momentary influence or to any more or less concealed evolution of the system which is the seat of this phenomenon), we have no reason whatever to abandon the hypothesis of a universal time, and every phenomenon whose law does not vary in the course of time confirms this hypothesis. What more can we ask of a natural law?” (Time and Method P 216). Professor Wolfgang Pauli had assisted Gonseth. It may be no wonder that Pauli’s “world clock” became manifest in his dream language. Writer Arthur Koestler refers to astronomer Firsof. “,,, the eminent astronomer, V. A. Firsoff suggested that ‘mind was a universal entity or interaction of the same order as electricity or gravitation, and that there must exist a modulus of transformation, analogous to Einstein’s famously equality E=mc squared, whereby ‘mind stuff’ could be equated with other entities of the physical world.” (Arthur Koestler, The Roots of Coincidence, p 63); Professor Pauli himself, as he collaborated with Dr. Carl Jung for a “unified vision” (physics/psychology) about “complimentary opposites” in one letter sent, "’Self’ It is clear that "nucleus" means the same as the individual center. But what does "radioactivity" mean in psychologi­cal terms? On the one hand it seems to indicate a gradual transformation of the center, and on the other hand an effect radiating outwards (rays!)” (Atom and Archetype: The Pauli/Jung Letters 1932–1958 p 12). Niels Bohr considered the two areas of discipline in the same way. “Bohr was convinced that complimentary was relevant not only to physics but also to psychology and to life itself” (Deciphering the Cosmic Number p 102). Einstein had praised Pauli. “No one studying this mature, grandly conceived work could believe that the author is a man of 21. One wonders what to admire most, the psychological understanding for the development of ideas, the sureness of mathematical deduction, the profound physical insight, the capacity for lucid systematic presentation, the complete treatment of the subject matter, or the sureness of critical appraisal” (Synchronicity: The Bridge Between Matter and Mind p 15), (Atom and Archetype: The Pauli/Jung Letters 1932–1938 p xiii). Einstein had been a frequent guest at the Jung mansion for dinners. Dr. Progoff pointed out, “It is interesting in this regard to note that the recent opening of Einstein’s private papers has disclosed that dreams and images played a very important role in Einstein’s creative life. Those luncheon conversations may have been more fruitful that Jung realized, especially since we now know that Einstein possessed a keen sensitivity to the deep levels of the psyche. It may, at some later tie, be very fruitful to study the relationship between Jung and Einstein more closely, particularly in view of Einstein’s interest in Hindu/Buddhist thought and his later description of the archetypal qualities of the relativity concept. “While Jung may have had an important psychological effect on Einstein, the theory of Relativity became the base and starting point for his own thinking about Synchronicity. At several points he seems to have been consciously seeking to develop a concept that would be the equivalent of the relativity theory with the added dimension of the psyche” (Ira Progoff, Jung, Synchronicity and Human Destiny, p 152). “Later in his life, Jung traced his idea of synchronicity to the influence of Albert Einstein, who held a professorship in Zurich in 1909-10 and again in 1912-1913. Jung wrote, ‘Professor Einstein was my guest on several occasions at dinner… These were very early days when Einstein was developing his first theory of relativity, [and] it was he who first started me off thinking about a possible relativity of time as well as space, and their psychic conditionality. More than thirty years later, this stimulus led to my relation with the physicist Professor W. Pauli and to my thesis of psychic synchronicity’” (Synchronicity: An Acausal Connecting Principle pp vi-vii). So far, whether it be the universe, the earth, social structures, an individual the pattern is the same. But what about lower life? Ants, termites, bee colonies for example. If we try to swat a bee, the individual does not have to know what happened. A swarm may step up to the plate to do something about it. Mold cells, without brains, at a certain stage emerge as slime mold exhibiting as if intelligent behavior and as if patterns similar to the neural pathways with memory. PENROSE! Sir Roger Penrose pointed at the a paradox that the universe after expansion becomes both BIG simultaneously is the SMALL. The same idea as modern and old thinking regarding the microcosm/macrocosm. One of Jung’s definition of “PSYCHE = The greatest intensity in the least amount of space” was noted by both Depth Psychologist, Dr. Marie-Louise in Psyche and Matter and Professor Roderick Main’s Jung on Synchronicity and the Paranormal. The stuff of the “mind” permeates everything the microcosm has almost all of the data of the macrocosm. They are mirror images. The mind and matter are different aspects of the same. David Hume envisioned the same idea. “Now if we survey the universe, so far as it falls under our knowl­edge, it bears a great resemblance to an animal or organized body, and seems actuated with a like principle of life and motion. A continual cir­culation of matter in it produces no disorder: a continual waste in every part is incessantly repaired; the closest sympathy is perceived through­out the entire system: and each part or member, in performing its proper offices, operates both to its own preservation and to that of the whole. The world, therefore, I infer, is an animal, and the Deity is the soul of the world, actuating it, and actuated by it” ( Dialogues Concerning Natural Religion). James Jean “Today there is a wide measure of agreement, which on the physical side of science approaches almost to unanimity, that the stream of knowledge is heading towards a non-mechanical reality; the universe begins to look more like a great thought than like a great machine. Mind no longer appears as an accidental intruder into the realm of matter; we are beginning to suspect that we ought rather to hail it as a creator and governor of the realm of matter...” ( The Mysterious Universe p. 137, 1937 ed.) It is as if the “gears of our consciousness” operate in the same way but at a different scale. The problem is that humans usually place themselves as the only observer and thereby imposes restrictions upon nature to answer the questions devised by man. Bertrand Russell reminded us, “It is natural to suppose that the observer is a human being or at least the mind but he is just as likely to be a photographic plate or clock. That is to say the odd results as to the difference between one ‘point of view’ and another are concerned with the ‘point of view’ in a sense applicable physical instruments just as much as to speak to people with perceptions” (The ABC of Relativity p 138).

Some people speculate that the brain is a quantum computer in that a single synapse encodes multiple bits simultaneously (multitasking) and that quantum computing requires the ‘many-worlds’ interpretation of quantum mechanics Can existing quantum computers be considered evidence for parallel universes?From a philosophical standpoint, for us to have free-will, there has to exist another world in which we could’ve chosen otherwise. This interpretation requires that much of our thinking actually occurs in parallel worlds whenever a choice must be confronted. Earman wrote a book about this. This would exclude the probabilistic ‘wavefunction collapse” interpretation and the deterministic ‘pilot wave interpretation’ of quantum mechanics. Nevertheless, I’ve always liked Elisabeth Anscomb’s view of determinism: just because the rules of a game are determined does not mean that the game is G. E. M. Anscombe Quote. This seems to leave room for free-will in some interpretations (although not in Anscombe’s) Battle of the two Elizabeths: are free will and physical determinism compatible? If you really want to break this all down into the philosophical nuts and bolts, you need to read Hume and Descartes. Nevertheless, our intuition tells us that free-will seems to result from consciousness, and consciousness can be defined as the brain telling itself what it is doing. That materialist standpoint is something I tried to describe here: Kirsten Hacker's answer to Can we call consciousness a state of matter, like solid, liquid, etc.?

No, consciousness can’t be described by physics, much less explained. The most basic aspect of this problem is that physics itself is a product of consciousness. It is impossible to look at consciousness from the outside; it is the one thing we can never “get behind” to see how it works. You have to use consciousness to look at consciousness. It is not physical, so there is nothing to measure. Here is an example of the problem:  We begin with a cup and we all know what a cup is. None of this matter has been destroyed, it all still exists in a different form, but this particular cup has completely ceased to exist. At what point exactly did this stop being a cup? The cup is not made of cup, it is made of a material that we have fashioned into a cup, but it could have been made into something else. We can all agree what a cup is, but we can make the size of a few atoms or the size of the universe and it is still a cup. We can have an infinite number of them or none at all. There is no physics that can explain this because we’re faced with the problem of only being able to use cups to explain what a cup is. It all becomes circular. The only way around this is to use consciousness to explain quantum physics. It doesn’t work the other way around.

It is important to note that consciousness cannot be explained WITHOUT quantum physics. Many physicists and neurobiologists (with the exception of Hameroff and Penrose, for example) assume that QM is not relevant to consciousness, because the brain is warm and wet, and quantum superpositions can’t generally last long in such environments. The “decoherence” time of such superpositions is generally calculated to be on the pico- or nanosecond scale, which is much faster than the “refresh” rate of human consciousness. HOWEVER, even if this is true, this does NOT imply that quantum physics is irrelevant to consciousness. Here’s an example. A person is using a Geiger counter to measure the radioactivity of a sample. When he hears a “click,” it is because a decay, which is a quantum event, was amplified to the point of creating an audible sound, which the person then consciously hears. In other words, when he hears the click, his conscious state becomes correlated to a QM event, and that conscious state is measurably distinct from one that is NOT correlated to that QM event. I explain this concept further, and also show why consciousness is not algorithmic, in this 1.5-hour explanation on YouTube. A quick summary (17 minutes) is here. So while we can’t yet say whether quantum physics causes consciousness, since we don’t yet know the cause of consciousness, we can say with some certainty that consciousness DEPENDS to some degree on quantum physics. Hope this is helpful.

It doesn’t. Although John Hagelin (featured in the new age film What the Bleep Do We Know) has promoted pseudoscientific connections with consciousness, based on his religion of transcendental meditation. He has a legit background in physics and quantum field theory, but he has gone on to use it to run for President (creating his own political party, the Natural Law party), preaching that transcendental meditation should be used as a replacement for our national defense system—bullets and missiles from hostile nations under his Presidency would be deflected by meditating monks. He also argues that meditation can reduce crime. He has a paper he wrote called “Is Consciousness the Unified Field?”, which supposedly has over 200 citations, but it was never actually published in a real physics journal, just in a fake journal he and other people who practice his religion created. And the citations are from parapsychologists and other crackpots. https://www.mum.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/hagelin.pdf Aside from Hagelin and maybe one or two other people like him, I don’t know of anyone else with a background in quantum field theory who believes quantum field theory has anything to say about consciousness. There are more who believe quantum mechanics itself may have some connection with consciousness, although the people who believe that are still considered somewhat fringe and the connections they argue for are far more subtle than what Hagelin says.

It’s highly unlikely. It seems pretty obvious that thing we regard as “consciousness” emerges at a level of description many orders of magnitude above the quantum level. Even if there are some quantum processes happening at the very “bottom” of the causal chain of events that results in human consciousness, those quantum processes won’t be essential to understanding the phenomenon of consciousness, because consciousness is something that emerges many layers of organization above that. The example I sometimes give is this – Imagine there was a 3 block area of your city that was plagued with traffic jams every day of the year, and you wanted to know why. Would you hire a city planner? Or would you hire a chemist to examine the properties of brake fluid under a microscope? Because after all, cars stop because of brake fluid, there is no denying that! Since traffic jams wouldn’t happen without brake fluid, obviously we should learn all we can about it, right? Yes, brake fluid is at the bottom level of the causal chain of events that leads to a traffic jam. But you will never learn anything important about traffic jams by studying brake fluid, because a traffic jam is an emergent phenomenon that takes place many layers of organization above the stopping of a single car. Likewise for QM and consciousness.

While we don’t completely understand consciousness it would seem unlikely it is affected by quantum uncertainty. While we can’t explain the aha moment of “I think therefore I am” we have explained a whole lot about how the physical brain creates the “mind”. Scientists have been able to explain how the brain can accept and store information from our five senses and access this information to develop thoughts that can be expressed externally if desired. This is done by physical stuff - neurons, neurotransmitters and chemicals like dopamine, oxytocin, serotonin, and endorphins. I realize I am going about this in a roundabout way but the point I’m trying to make is that the fact that you can think, walk, talk and store memories is because of physical processes that are occurring on the same macro level of matter that we interact with all the time. There is a hierarchy to this “matter” that we see, feel or measure with instruments and this “matter” is many levels above the quantum world of elementary particles like photons and electrons. All of stuff above is just groundwork for the answer to your question. By the time the randomness or uncertainty that exists in the quantum world has risen to our level of complex molecules reacting in chemical and physical interactions instead of quantum fluctuations - here it is - quantum decoherence has already transformed the gadzillions of wave functions (with their superposition of possible observable values) into a bunch of what appears at our macro level to be "classically" observable stuff. That includes the stuff in your brain that allows you to think and do other things. Which means that there isn’t any quantum uncertainty going on in your brain that would be influencing the development of consciousness or as some think, the basis of free will.

Can quantum physics explain consciousness? As a theoretical discipline, physics has become increasingly mysterious, and many prominent physicists have bought into a cognitive bias that is patterned on Eastern mysticism, including Werner Heisenberg, Erwin Schrödinger, Eugene Wigner, and Freeman Dyson. The jury’s still out on whether this mindset is simply an eccentricity of genius level insight or whether quantum physics can actually explain consciousness as a “collapse of the wave function” at the quantum level, as hypothesized by Wigner, or as Dyson argued that “mind, as manifested by the capacity to make choices, is to some extent inherent in every electron." See: Quantum mind - Wikipedia

Materialism does not appear to be able to explain ‘the hard problem’ in neuroscience; namely how does subjective experience emerge from the electrical impulses in the brain? Hence neuroscientists are increasingly turning to Panpsychism to explain it. Materialism tries to explain consciousness in terms of objective facts describing the dynamics and behaviour of matter, however this says nothing about what matter actually is. Panpsychism posits that the fundamental constituents of matter are ‘quanta of experience’ (qualia). Materialism draws from an entirely classical view of consciousness. Panpsychism does not limit itself this way, but it is still difficult to accept there could be quantum information processing going on in the very warm and noisy environment of the brain, since quantum states usually have to be cooled to near -273 degrees and kept causally isolated to prevent decoherence. Since it is difficult if not impossible to explain consciousness classically, then Nature must have found a way to preserve such states long enough to do useful computing with. Penrose/Hameroff have an extensive/detailed model for how this might work (Orch OR with quantum cellular automata on microtubules inside each neuron linked by gap junctions). It is a controversial theory and not widely accepted precisely because of the decoherence issue, however, neuroscience may have no choice but to accept it if it cannot explain consciousness with classical physics alone. Here is a recent article from a reputable source that may begin to address the decoherence issue in warm environments; It's a Quantum World Record: 15 Trillion Smokin' Hot Atoms Entangled. Therefore in answer to the question, one concludes consciousness will require both classical and quantum physics to explain it.

It doesn’t matter what a physicist says consciousness is, it only matters what a neurologist says it is. Please read Descartes’ Error by neurologist Antonio Damasio (1994) and his subsequent two books elaborating on the somatic basis for consciousness and other cognitive functions. That said, it seems you may be referring to what was known as the Copenhagen Interpretation of quantum physics (QM), it which the word “observe” is synonymous with“detect / measure”. It is a mistake in word usage and meaning. Machines do not “observe”; only aware animals do that, and there is no effect of animal awareness / consciousness / observation on any quantum scale energetic transaction. All the QM fuss is about how the machine that detects / measures the quantum scale energetic transaction cannot be separated from the transaction itself, and often the effect of the machine on detection / measurement cannot be extricated from the outcome, or mathematically corrected for the intervention which renders the detection / measurement dubious if not downright useless. Consciousness and physics is a bad mix of ideas, supplying the New Age way of thinking a large pile of fodder for more nonsensical concepts than can be straightened out in any answer to questions that emerge from these egregious misunderstandings of how reality actually works.

I am one of the few neuroscientists or physicists who think that a quantum theory of consciousness is well-motivated and plausible. Below I briefly sketch why I think that. To be fair, you should first know that most experts in neuroscience and physics who have considered this question would say what Steve Zara said: “The brain is a vast collection of neural networks which operate through electrical and chemical interactions. There is no place in that for any quantum-mechanical strangeness.” Temperature objection: Many scientists believe that it is implausible that a macroscopic quantum state could survive in a warm brain. This opinion is typically based on calculations in simple models that assume thermodynamic equilibrium in brain tissue (Tegmark 2000). But an older simple model (Frohlich) demonstrates how energy flow through a system (i.e. steady-state metabolism, not at thermal equilibrium) of molecular dipoles can organize it into stable coherent states even at high temperatures. So in my opinion a quantum substrate for consciousness in the brain is not ruled out. But why would one consider such an “exotic” hypothesis when current understanding of neural dynamics seems to account for a wide range of behavioral and cognitive phenomena? It is very popular to deride theoretical arguments, but here is a simple argument that motivates the idea that consciousness requires a quantum physical description. Our states of consciousness are intrinsically unified; they are irreducible wholes. But there are no irreducible wholes in classical physics. Really. Quantum physics on the other hand describes the dynamics of irreducible wholes, because that’s what quantum states are. Thus the quantum brain or quantum consciousness or quantum mind approach has the potential to solve the “phenomenal binding problem” at a fundamental level. This should not be dismissed lightly because synchrony in a classical brain model (a la Singer) cannot do this (I said why above), despite protests you may hear from well educated people. One can also note that despite impressive successes classical neural network theory has not yet managed to account for the full range of human cognitive abilities, even if we recklessly decide to neglect consciousness. Yes (classical) computers can beat us at face recognition and Go now, but current models simply do not capture the flexibility of our “common sense.” Quantum computation in a brain could give it significant advantages over a classical brain (e.g. Quantum Associative Memory). Quantum physics is not “exotic” or “strange” to Nature; it is Nature. A variety of “circumstantial” experimental evidence is consistent with the possibility I am arguing for, that a macroscopic quantum state in the brain underlies our consciousness and mind. For example, Context effects produced by question orders reveal quantum nature of human judgments. From the biophysical side, ultraweak light radiation emitted by all living tissue (“biophotons”) has been shown by Popp et al to exhibit a non-equilibrium distribution demonstrating the existence of an underlying coherent state. Such leakage of coherent light radiation is predicted by certain quantum models of memory and consciousness (Del Giudice, Vitiello). Aside from the temperature objection addressed above, another common objection to the hypothesis that a quantum process underlies consciousness, is the assertion that “there is no place” for quantum effects in the brain. This attitude stems from familiarity with the deterministic Hodgkin-Huxley equations which govern neural dynamics like Newton’s Laws in physics. If these equations determine everything neurons do, how could there be a role for some additional quantum ghost? But synaptic transmission among neurons in the central nervous system is extremely “noisy” or random or “unreliable.” In other words, synaptic transmission in the brain is probabilistic, and the transmission probabilities vary with time. We do not necessarily know every factor that can affect synaptic transmission probability at each synapse from moment to moment. This apparent randomness represents a “place” where a hypothetical quantum state could interact with the well-known neural machinery to guide adaptive behavior. As a concrete example, the theory of Hameroff and Penrose posits a collective quantum state in brain microtubules. The microtubule state could condition the state of the photon field inside microtubules, which in turn could modulate synaptic transmission probabilities via liquid-crystal actin molecules that reside near the synaptic junction (the microtubules tend to be “aimed” down neuronal axons toward the synapse). This is analogous to how liquid-crystal gates function in optical computers. This is one specific example to demonstrate that the brain’s neural networks are not completely determined classical machines even in the mainstream description, so one can reasonably consider how a hypothetical additional factor—the quantum conscious process—might interact with the known neural machinery. In summary, classical neuroscience has not been able to account for consciousness so far, and the quantum consciousness hypothesis is not ruled out.

You can't use QM to explain consciousness untill you understand QM. I knew I understood QM, at least in a general way, when I realized that Probability was completely mathematical as opposed to being a function of observational uncertainty, i.e. local realism. When I looked at mathematics as essentially comprised of logic bits, X/not-X, I understood how quantum matter/antimatter entanglement worked. You cannot have X without not-X. So on the level of local realism, you cannot create a matter particle without at the same time creating an antimatter particle. Looking back I realized that X/not-X are logically entangled just as particle pairs are and that the local realism of particle/antiparticle entanglement was based on the logical entanglement of X/not-X. To understand quantum spin entanglement I had to dig a little deeper into the common origin of Logic and Probability. What I realized is that both Logic and Probability are based on Possibility. Possibility has every possible freedom, the foremost of which is that its somethingness aspect and its nothingness aspects have the freedom to in a limited way disassociate. One basic way this dissociation is observed is as the '/' in X/not-X which separation gives rise to Logic. A more extreme form of dissociation is seen as the collapse of the probability function and the manifestation of local realism. Local realism occurs because more extreme dissociation is also expansion i.e. Time and Space. Finally, one of the important possible ways (or freedoms) by which the aspects of Possibility can disassociate is by opposite spin, i.e. quantum spin entanglement. How you and I know this to be true is because we are essentially Possibility so this is all of our shared history. We know it not because we observe it locally but apriori. On the apriori level QM and Consciousness are self explanatory.

Quantum phenomenon can't explain consciousness but certainly consciousness influences quantum system. Our universe exists as quantum fields but not physical and the waves emanating on vibration is what we call wave function, a mathematical construct. Its weirdness confirms religious expression of consciousness is possible and not based on blind faith. According to quantum “"The wave function is the particle spread out over space and describes all the various possible states of the particle and all various possible states of time including past , present and future “. Further wave function is non-physical and it is a mathematical construct. Only on observation or measurement it collapsed and take a localised position out of possible state , the position of which we can't determine before observation. We may relate the quantum field to God ,an infinite,eternal omnipresent existence -universal consciousness” and it is formless and beyond our mind to grasp. In the same manner quantum mechanics regards the quantum field as providing wave function with the potentiality to manifest in any possible localised state of existence. We may relate this to the unmanifested state of reality that contains the infinite and various possible states of Brahman (God) across the space and time. In this manner Brahman behaves as the quantum wave function where as Atman (self) represents the ripples or excitation of the quantum field and everything that exists in the universe represents the collapsed measurement of the wave function in localised reality (manifested realities of Brahman-universal consciousness) Please note this is merely a non -physical representation of the infinite in the microscopic realm. Reality-universal consciousness is inconceivable as it is beyond our limited ,conditioned mind..

Everything is made out of atoms. Atoms are described quantum mechanically. So quantum mechanics can explain everything. Right? Ok, explain how a sewing machine works. Quantum mechanics doesn’t enter into it, does it. Do we need or want to use quantum mechanics to explain consciousness? I think most of us consider consciousness an emergent property of mind. There’s debate over whether machines will achieve consciousness and whether there’s any way to tell when/if it happens. Around 50 years ago Marvin Minsky said “A brain is a computer made out of meat.” Examination of brain structures and improved understanding of neurons, neural connections, and how they work suggests there’s something to that flip statement. We may not need to go beyond chemistry to understand what goes on in neurons. Neurons do seem to be rearranging their molecules in the process of learning and adapting: chemistry probably can handle all that, but who knows? Each neuron seems to be a small computer. I think we’d all be pretty surprised of some of them turn out to be quantum computers. That would be quite an achievement for a computer made out of meat.

Some people argue unsuccessfully that quantum weirdness explains consciousness. When the subjects of consciousness, self awareness, the mind and free will are discussed philosophically we do run into serious paradoxes. It is tempting to bring quantum arguments into these discussions claiming that it is all because quantum states have random and non-intuitive behavior but there is no scientific evidence to support this. The reality is that consciousness is related to brain function, mostly to the thalamus region and the cortex and everything we currently know about brain activity is based on nerve synapses (ends of axons) which are classical electric pulses that have no quantum nature because at the strength of these electric pulses all quantum effects are already observed and therefore lost any quantum coherence. That doesn’t exclude the possibility that quantum effect are involved in nerve activity but at the current state of science there is no basis for this assumption.

Yes. But everything relies on quantum mechanics. A house brick relies on quantum mechanics, and it shows no signs of intelligence or mind. Consciousness relies on quantum mechanics because quantum mechanics is the foundation of all mechanics - it describes the behaviour of all particles that make up our bodies. If what you mean is - does consciousness rely on strange aspects of quantum mechanics such as entanglement - then the answer is no. This is because the brain is warm and wet, and so a very bad environment for large-scale quantum entanglement to exist. The brain also operates very slowly. If we scale up the time that a typical quantum entanglement exists to a second, then a thought would take tens of thousands of years. It’s not just that consciousness doesn’t involve quantum mechanics, it’s also that there is nothing about consciousness that quantum mechanics would help to explain.

The same way Maxwell’s field equations explain the designated hitter rule: it doesn’t. A dude named Roger Penrose thinks it does. He’s a very smart fellow—mathematician, philosopher, professor at Oxford—but he isn’t a neurobiologist nor a cognitive scientist. He invented a hypothesis about quantum consciousness (it’s the microtubules! I seen ‘em!), but it’s not supported by experimental evidence and it isn’t widely accepted.

Currently consciousness is not understood. Not even close. It is one of the least understood subjects we humans cogitate on. Quantum mechanics is another. Neither the old quantum mechanics nor the new quantum mechanics (QFT) explains consciousness. Well, let me qualify that. Since we don’t understand consciousness, how would we even know if QM explained it? We wouldn’t. But from my own perspective (a minority view, I’m quite sure), quantum mechanics as we have it today, circa 2017, doesn’t even explain quantum mechanics. Doesn’t even try. Doesn’t even care to. So there’s that. The equations allow predictions; they do not promote understanding. True quantum mechanics lies hidden somewhere beyond the differential equations. A whole new landscape to explore.

That would be like having a quantum theory of how car engines work. There is a quantum theory for how atoms bond into molecules: good old quantum mechanics, QM. Now, everything is made of atoms, including conscious brains, but to build a theory of how brains work, QM is way too low-level, and has nothing useful to say. It’s better to look at information processing in and between neurons. An information theory would be the same whether or not the building blocks are described by QM or something else. To understand car engines, you need to know zero QM. You just need mechanics. A bit of thermodynamics helps. Or take a computer made of transistors. To understand how to write a python program for your computer, you don’t need to know anything about transistors. So even though you need QM to understand transistors, there’s no “quantum theory for programming in python.” The only folks who speak of “quantum consciousness” are spiritualists trying to impress. I’ve read quite a lot, and never come across one who seems to understand QM. They borrow words, say something vague, sell their books…

That has been my big beef in Quantum theory, debating observation, and consciousness with no working definition for consciousness - for over a century… a cat paradox that negates in every debate of superposition the cat as being conscious Bohr and Einstein, Heisenberg, Schrodinger, Wigner, Dirac, all debating a thing without defining it. I have a very thick text where I define consciousness, suitable within the framework of Quantum Theory, religion, philosophy, human perception and so on. rather than be accused of ‘pimping my texts’ on quora, just go to drbray where you can read my lay texts for free. Just click on a text and download the pdf file. Note that these are my lay texts, not my grad texts. Also note that Temporal Mechanics 101 is under revision and I hope to get the edition ready by July 2017. The last chapter on ‘Mass’ is currently the hold-up. others are also welcome to do so. remember, if you disagree with my work, that’s fine. as the retired Sr.Director of R&D of advanced physics projects for the DOD where I spent 30 years, if my views were orthodox; I’d never have been offered my first job there, nor climbed the ladder - nor have I hired any scientists with orthodox views. I can hire a secretary to do key word searches through college and grad texts to get orthodox answers. If you cannot think outside the box, you are a boxling; just go to wikipedia.

No, it isn’t and probably never will. The architects of quantum theory had another view, though. The famous thought experiment “Schrodingers cat” is an example of how consciousness interacts with the quantum world. Physicist don’t claim any role for consciousness in quantm theory.They keep concluding that a measurement by any system will collaps the quantum wave function. This system can be any another “classical system” , conscious or not. Philosophers, however, and even some mathematicians and some physicists suspect a more intensive relation between the quantum world and (non- local) consciousness.

What is a good explanation of the theory of quantum theory of consciousness? To boil it down to one word: Malarkey. It’s something come up with by people who don’t actually understand quantum physics or neurology, but *do* understand how to write books about quantum woo to sell on new-age websites to people even less informed than themselves. We don’t know all the details yet, but we do know that consciousness doesn’t involve quantum mechanics, it’s an emergent phenomenon caused by having a hundred billion neurons with a trillion interconnections. And it’s the interconnections that matter, not the quantum woo.

The double slit experiment holds a potntial (agreed upon by John A.Wheeler protege of Einstein, former Head of Physics Princeton University, developer of renouned theorys and discoveries including the Many Worlds Interpretation of Quantum Mechanics and the Everett Wheeler Genesis Observer Created Universe Theory) to involve the consiousness of the measurer in determining it's wave or paticle like state and also other quantum measurements involving a binary choice of 1 or 0. It at times seems there are 'two camp's’ of Quantum understood potential thinkers, those who agree with Wheeler's supposition and those who vehemently deny it. Those denying could not sufficiently come close to Wheeler's direct imputs with the giants of Quantum theory - Bohr, Bohm, Feynman or Einstein (and more) nor could they have reached his level of prestige. So before in an 'only mathematical thinking’ manner consciousness is dismissed, I suggest they 'pause’ the math and study consiousness for a period - Especially Leibniz, then, take a deep breath, open their mind and regard the double slit experiment as though 'viewing anew', and ask if anything you learned on your journey 'changed’ your 'overly mathematically bound psyche?’ Yes. Quantum causes reaction. - by just being unfathomable (so far) - particularly to Physicist's (as a whole) consiousness - when arguing about its implications.

Quantum physics could help reveal some aspects of ‘consciousness’. Below is a section from a research published on SciVenue that in my opinion answers the question: “The statement that quantum theory may provide with new findings on the molecular level is indeed, a rather interesting one. It is definitely worth a try to attempt to research the nature of consciousness via the microscopic aspects. The brain consists of thousands of neurons that could hold some answers. It is also an organ that scientists do not know much about. There are many findings that remain unknown when it comes to the brain. However, unlike consciousness, people are aware that the brain is a real tangible thing and it is much easier to study it and come to certain conclusions. This is not the case with consciousness. Therefore, it would be beneficial to apply the principle of quantum theory to the brain in order to research it. Quantum mechanics could provide with answers to the unknown parts of the brain, which, in turn, could provide with some clues on what consciousness is. Maybe, after the brain is studied on a microscopic level in more detail, it will provide researchers closer to find answers to the question why.” Source

There is not yet consensus on quantum consciousness theories. They are in the minority, consensus wise. There is, however, consensus that consciousness is “computationally bound elemental qualities like redness and greenness.” You can see this emerging expert consensus in the camp now being called “Representational Qualia Theory”. The only disagreement is the nature of qualia. Some people, like Hameroff are predicting that it is “quantum”. The leading consensus is predicting it is not quantum, just “functional”. My bet is on simple “Molecular Materialism”. Quantum theories provide no insights as to how to bridge the “Explanatory Gap”, the only real hard problem. Thanks to the work of these experts, building consensus around the best theories,“Representational Qualia Theory” has emerged as a falsifiable way to bridge this “Explanatory Gap” and discover things like which physics it is that do have a redness quality. Experimentalists just need to stop being “qualia blind.” We will be monitoring this consensus around the best theories as experimentalist stop being qualia blind, so they can do the described experiments and falsify all but THE ONE true theory of qualia, forcing all the experts to abandon false theories into one scientific consensus camp. My prediction is that quantum theories will be some of the first to be falsified by this type of experimentation.

I’ve read in the book Physics in Mind: A Quantum View of the Brain 1 from Werner Loewenstein that the neurons may operate in two levels: a ‘classical’ one and a ‘quantum’ one. The quantum one would happen before measurements on the atoms that make synapses take place. In other words, before the collapse of the wave function. After the collapse, the classical structure would take place. This is an interesting idea and goes in tandem with Roger Penrose view (as expressed in Shadows of The Mind and The Emperor’s New Mind) that somehow our brain manages to keep all it’s cells in quantum superposition to make its calculations. I think this idea a little “too much”. But Loewenstein’s idea may be a middle ground that could be tested and someday somehow turned into some kind of technology.

Nothing. It says nothing. Quantum physics studies the behavior of particles under very specific circumstances. Their “logic” is usually something like this. Consciousness is mysterious Quantum mechanics is mysterious therefore Consciousness is quantum mechanics. Anyone that tells you that quantum physics says something about consciousness is selling you woo, but trying to make it sound sciencey. Yes, this even includes some well known physicists.
No. We don't even know what consciousness is.

No way. Consciousness is the result of bio-electromagnetic actions. These complex and delicate interactions are the product of years and years of evolution of life. Of tests with errors and successes. Of tests and proofs that the eternity of the universe can be allowed. Quantum mechanics is only an approximation to the truth that the universe is dynamic electromagnetic, and that its sole purpose is to survive eternity. For this, it has several tools and universal laws: The first is that energy can not be created or destroyed. That the anti energy, in addition to having the same role, can not be annulled with energy. Similarly antimatter can not be canceled or neutralized with matter. The only thing that matters for the universe is that nothing stops, that everything moves: it must survive eternity or it will collapse. Armando Molina Bariloche

Is hard to avoid a link between QM and C. That possibility was admitted in the 1930s by the Hungarian physicist Eugene Wigner. "It follows that the quantum description of objects is influenced by impressions entering my consciousness," Wheeler had thoughts that presence of conscious beings created the reality which we see called it ”participatory universe” What if, Penrose asked, there are molecular structures in our brains that are able to alter their state in response to a single quantum event. Could not these structures then adopt a superposition state, just like the particles in the double slit experiment? And might those quantum superpositions then show up in the ways neurons are triggered to communicate via electrical signals? “Quantum consciousness is widely derided as mystical woo, but it just will not go away”

Since quantum physics attempts to describe the behavior of the universe at its most basic, subatomic level, there have been attempts to link this state with cosmic consciousness which, according to Vedic philosophy, underlies all other forms of consciousness. Some research along these lines has been done at places like Maharishi International University, through such means as measuring the brain waves of long-term practitioners of transcendental meditation and comparing them to their subjective experiences, but most mainstream quantum physicists who aren't part of the TM movement regard this as speculative at best.

What is a good explanation of the theory of quantum theory of consciousness? I think the theory is that the mysteries are somehow tied together. Upon learning more about the mind I think less of this. The best I can come up with on my own is that consciousness is more plausible in a world governed by quantum mechanics. Particles seem to “know” things they can’t possibly know. Even that might be taking things to far.

One (of several) interpretations of QM involves lots of hand-waving about the nature of the “observer”. That term is a bit unfortunate, because it leads people to think the observer must be a person, and thus leads them to think consciousness has something to do with it. But it’s possible to reason about information and QM and wavefunction collapse without evoking consciousness. But people like to think that “spooky” things should go together (not to imply that there’s anything spooky about consciousness, and not really much about QM either).
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Roksana Parvin Yasmin

response.answer_text: We have no idea what consciousness is. Some say it is an internal brain process. Some say it is our connection to an energy force universe wide. Within the mystery of quantum forces there are “energetic environments” yet explained. Some people like to think that part of this unexplained energy is the source of consciousness that connects us to all living things. There is no scientific evidence for that being true. but it may be fun to think about. For some it becomes a source of solace and for others religious mumbo-jumbo with no place in science.

Yes. If you think about consciousness as something that thinks, then acts in a cycle. Then that fits into the framework of the Schrondinger’s eqation, which describes energy in terms of potential and kinetic energies. Thinking in this case is the potential energy. Acting is the kinetic part. Understanding emotion is at the heart of consciousness. It’s like consciousness is the process of balancing ones emotions. I model consciousness through a feedback loop of: energy impulse -> senses -> thoughts -> actions -> and state of being.

The following is just my opinion.Consciousness is something, physics cannot explain.Quantum mechanics gives a nice possibility for an interaction of consciousness with the physical universe, but there are other possibilities you might think of.Quantum mechanics is a solid experimental fact. I also consider consciousness as a fact. So, why not use the elements already there and inven5 a new one.For me, my interpretation of a measurment gives a totally consistent merge of physics and esotherics. Unfortunately, both groups speak totally different languages and no mutual understanding results. Some rather deep understanding of quantum mechanics is required to grwsp my theory. This level of understanding is missin even with many university trained physicists.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Reginald Cristofer Rogoff

response.answer_text: Consciousness is created by the interaction between particles in the human brain. Quantum mechanics explains the basis on which interaction between particles takes place. For example, according to relational quantum mechanics, there is no observer independent reality. Any microscopic or macroscopic, conscious or unconscious, living or non-living physical system or subsystem can be an observer. The universe consists of interactions between physical systems. These interactions are real only relative to the observing physical system. So, the reality experienced by each one of us is real only relative to each one of us. Once we die, both us and our relative reality would disappear.

No. We are starting to understand the function of the brain, and we recognise symptoms of what happens when the brain does something. On the other hand, we have no idea how it can order its activity in a coherent fashion, as opposed to some mush of signals, and we have no idea why it can say “I am.”

Here’s the problem. There are two distinctions to consider here. First: the fact that we are conscious. Second: the fact that we have experience of the everyday world. It has been said that quantum theory doesn’t explain how the everyday world of determinism can arise from quantum indeterminacy. It does. How so precisely? I don’t think anyone can say. So how then could quantum theory explain the fact that we are conscious of things when it doesn’t explain how the things of our experience arise? On the surface of it, doesn’t it seem that being aware of things and the existence of things would result from categorically different processes? All that we know of cosmology comes from reverse engineering the past from what we know about a given present. But that project doesn’t know how to deal with the fact that we know about our present in the first place. How reverse engineer the fact that we know? There isn’t a science of knowing, but that we know is just as much a fact as the facts making up our existence, to paraphrase Daniel Robinson the late philosopher. And it doesn’t make sense to invent a science of knowing from quantum theory, that theory having what we know about as its subject.

I assume you want the technical, scientific explanation. Okay. Brain + Quantum Magic = Consciousness Proof of the existence of Quantum Magic: None. Theoretical Properties of Quantum Magic: Unknown. Agreement with existing theories: None. Mechanism by which Quantum Magic could create consciousness: Unknown. Way of detecting Quantum Magic experimentally: Unknown. Reason for hypothesizing Quantum Magic: Argument from Ignorance. Supported by which branches of science: None. Science papers published on Quantum Magic: None.

Theoretical physicist, Richard Feynman said: “An understanding of the physical laws [of quantum physics] doesn’t give an understanding of the significance of the world in any way.” Feynman considered quantum physics part of a “hierarchy.” That is, the quantum realm underlies ordinary material reality as building blocks on the subatomic scale…but does not directly affect the science of everyday material reality.

Laws of nature regarding consciousness and laws of nature from quantum physics (not just quantum mechanics) as depicted by quantum “apparent” phenomenology are both aliens to our scale's phenomenology. As told by Ockham razor, a simpler hypothesis is probably better than a more complicated one. Why nature would have created various sets of laws of nature where just two were largely enough ? One are the classical physics laws of nature, intensively used at our human scale. The other set of laws of nature would be the one used by the quantum realm and the consciousness realm, both being the same one.

Quantum mechanics and consciousness are two fields of modern science that are not completely understood yet. This led to an idea that maybe both of them are related to each other. Quantum mechanics wiped out the idea of a deterministic universe. Observations can change an experiment’s output in quantum mechanics. This can be directed to consciousness as observations can only be made by conscious beings. Thus conscious beings can change the physical world just by their observations. Probabilistic insights to quantum mechanics like Qbism helps in uniting consciousness and quantum mechanics to some level.

Absolutely nothing. The most mainstream science says about consciousness is that it is “emergent” and arises naturally when a computing mechanism becomes sufficiently powerful and sophisticated. I don’t see how that can possibly be true, but other than that science says nothing about consciousness.

Consciousness has not been studied properly by any branch of science leave alone quantum physics. Consciousness is basically a very tricky entity. While we tend to ascribe the role of observer to the consciousness, we make a fundamental mistake by separating consciousness from the outside world. In fact the existence of any entity is part of consciousness. While Quantum physics has established that observation causes reality, it is only a tip of the truth. The real truth concerns the fact that consciousness is spread throughout the universe and is the basis for existence as space-time-matter-energy universe.
Quantum physics, or physics in general, says nothing about consciousness, it is not in it’s domain. It is rather a question shared between biology and psychology (with a touch of philosophy).

No. Coincidents are never really 'meant to happen'. Some people may think they were, but no physics can explain why they happen. They are just moments where, for example, someone thinks of the number 237 and the same number 237 appears on a screen without any common reason.

No. Quantum physics, like classical physics (e.g. Newton’s laws), has no particular connection with consciousness. However, quantum physics will surely play a role in future bio-chemical study of the human brain, because quantum physics is an essential component of understanding chemical reactions.

There is no quantum theory of consciousness. Evolution would never produce consciousness that allowed linear superpositions of conscious states because consciousness must function to drive decisions related to the environment and the environment at the level of life is necessarily classical.

Not in any useful sense. (Yes, all objects, including brains, are made of atoms which are best understood in quantum mechanics, but that’s it.) Lots of annoying New Age people sell their ideas using scientific-sounding language. Don’t buy it.

I do not think so, although I do believe understanding quantum physics may affect consciousness. The study of the “designs” of life has recently developed to spiritual associations. These developments are fundamental for the human consciousness overtime. Quantum is considered to be the “spiritual” study of laws and attractions on Earth. The physical laws, and quantum laws affect every aspect of life, on Earth. Basically, I believe the understanding and application of the quantum physics theory (how attractions affect us individually) changes our consciousness levels.
Physics says nothing about consciousness. Quantum physics, in some interpretations, has the concept of an observer “collapsing the wave function” but the observer could be a scientific instrument.

Quantum mechanics says that consciousness arises due to a specific arrangement of atoms and molecules in our brain. This specific and complex arrangement leads to thoughts and feelings and other things.

There is no such theory. Not clear QM is needed or not, but there’s no theory of any sort that’s convincing. The ones you hear of border on word salad. They make no definite predictions and can’t be falsified.
No. This is just a way some people want to “explain” mysteries yet ununderstood by some kind of magic, sometime picked up in some physics sounding mysterious and ununderstood by these people.
No! Can a bunch of superstitious child abusers explain reality? If your read the christian manifesto you will find a load crap.
Concisiousness can't neither be explained by humans or any other living objectiles, computing does make no sense in this process.
Why? Is your Quantum on the fritz and in need of service, no longer reliable? And even if so, have you ever tried to FIND a Quantum Mechanic?
